alert.note: Alert for Carver; Dakota; Hennepin; Scott (Minnesota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 06 at 8:49AM CDT until May 07 at 7:00AM CDT by NWS Minneapolis
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Minnesota... Minnesota River at Morton affecting Renville and Redwood Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Minnesota... Minnesota River at Savage affecting Scott, Hennepin, Dakota and Carver Counties. Minnesota River at Montevideo affecting Yellow Medicine, Lac qui Parle and Chippewa Counties. ...The Flood Warning is cancelled for the following rivers in Minnesota... Minnesota River at Granite Falls HWY 212 affecting Yellow Medicine, Renville and Chippewa Counties. .Showers and thunderstorms have produced 1 to over 2 inches of rainfall since Friday. However, the rainfall has not been widespread enough to cause any issues with our downwards trend in river levels. We expect to see a continued downward trend despite further showers and thunderstorms through the weekend. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL TOMORROW MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Minnesota River at Savage. * WHEN...Until tomorrow morning. * IMPACTS...At 702.0 feet, Barge loading affected at Port Cargill, and other flood prevention measures are begun. Water begins to impact Black Dog Road in Burnsville. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 800 AM CDT Saturday, the stage was 702.1 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 800 AM CDT Saturday was 702.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage this afternoon and continue falling to 698.4 feet next Saturday morning. - Flood stage is 702.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 702.1 feet on 04/09/1967. &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.
